Package ver14.SharedClasses.Game.Moves

Enum Class Direction

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Enum<Direction>
ver14.SharedClasses.Game.Moves.Direction
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<Direction>, Constable
public enum Direction extends Enum<Direction>
Direction - represents a moving direction on a board. sort of like a vector. has an offset that is added to a certain location or bitboard, in order to achieve movement in that direction. the general direction map looks like this:
-9 -8 -7
-1 loc 1
7 8 9

Author:
Bezalel Avrahami (bezalel3250@gmail.com)

    Description
    static Direction[]
    ALL_DIRECTIONS
    The All directions.
    static List<Direction>
    ALL_USED_DIRECTIONS
    The All used directions.
    long
    andWith
    some directions need to filter false positives. for example: moving left one square from the left-most column, will overflow to the previous row. to fix this problem some directions have a andWith value they have to perform a bitwise and with, after every offset. to cancel the false positives. in the left direction example, the andWith is the whole board but the right-most column
    int
    asInt
    an int for quick access by index.

    lookup
     
    (package private) static PlayerColor
    normalPerspective
    the perspective the offset is correct for. if the moving piece's color is not this value the direction need to be flipped.

    perspective​(PlayerColor playerColor)
    gets the correct perspective for the provided player color.this is necessary because for example: a white pawn push(U) is the exact opposite of a black pawn push (D). so the perspective needs to be in relation to the moving color.

    • normalPerspective

      static final PlayerColor normalPerspective
      the perspective the offset is correct for. if the moving piece's color is not this value the direction need to be flipped.

    • lookup

      private static final HashMap<Integer,​Direction> lookup

    • andWith

      public final long andWith
      some directions need to filter false positives. for example: moving left one square from the left-most column, will overflow to the previous row. to fix this problem some directions have a andWith value they have to perform a bitwise and with, after every offset. to cancel the false positives. in the left direction example, the andWith is the whole board but the right-most column

    • offset

      public final int offset
      The actual offset.

      an int for quick access by index.

    • perspective

      public Direction perspective​(PlayerColor playerColor)
      gets the correct perspective for the provided player color.this is necessary because for example: a white pawn push(U) is the exact opposite of a black pawn push (D). so the perspective needs to be in relation to the moving color.
